results.title: Icarus = Icare (K)
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Wolf Koenig and Paul Bochner
results.brief_description: The Greek myth retold by film animation, accompanied by music for flute written by Eldon Rathburn. Music, drawing, colour and movement here follow a moving classic restraint. Daedalus, inventor of many things, provides the wings to escape from Crete but Icarus, his son, impetuously flies too high. In this film, artist and composer share equal pleasure in the telling, with a feeling the audience will share. A film without words. Award: Oberhausen
results.creator_credit_for_label: ONF | NFB, Wolf Koenig and Paul Bochner

results.title: Icarus
results.creator_credit: Outlook, Film Australia, Don Murray, Antonio Colacino and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Man, it seems, has long craved to fly as the birds fly, silently propelled only by the forces of nature. Some get towed aloft in large gliders; others, like flying men harnessed to flimsy wings, launch themselves from wind swept cliff tops. Icarus is a view of both forms of the gliding sport in which the viewer gains the same sense of freedom, of elevation above the problems of the earthbound as do the men who choose to gain recreation in this exciting way. No spoken commentary.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Outlook, Film Australia, Don Murray, Antonio Colacino and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Icaros
results.creator_credit: Amos Winikoff, John Bird and David Atkinson
results.brief_description: An adaptation to film of an exercise in dance and music. The animation reveals new aspects of what was an event of true improvisation. A hand drawn dance sequence which revolves around elements of the sun, light, and joy.

results.title: Ibrahim
results.creator_credit: Ivan Gaal and Material Production Curriculum Branch Education Dept of Victoria
results.brief_description: This film has been made to provoke discussion of issues about racial prejudice. It tells the story of Ibrahim, a twelve-year-old Lebanese boy, who comes to Melbourne from war-torn Beirut. He goes straight into a post-primary school knowing no English and haunted by the horrors he has seen. Cast includes Sherif Abada. Based on a story by Jane Watson. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Iberian Peninsula: Spain and Portugal
results.brief_description: A brief survey of modern Spain and Portugal showing the chief topographic and climatic features of th Peninsula, and portraying people at work in various types of agricultural pursuits and in fishing, mining and industry. Emphasises especially the Peninsula’s limited industrialisation and the age-old agricultural techniques generally employed in the region.

results.title: Ian Chappell on cricket
results.creator_credit: South Australian Film Corporation, Vincent O'Donnell and Terry Jennings
results.brief_description: Australian Captain, Ian Chappell, and three other Test cricket players, Ashley Mallett, Terry Jenner and Eric Freeman, demonstrate the elements of the game. Using freeze-frame and slow motion techniques, the subtlety of various batting strokes and bowling deliveries are revealed by the experts, from the way a wrist is turned to the intricate foot-work required.
results.creator_credit_for_label: South Australian Film Corporation, Vincent O’Donnell and Terry Jennings

results.title: Ian Burns: in the telling interview
results.creator_credit: ACMI, Kim Montgomery and Csilla Csongvay
results.brief_description:
New York based Australian artist Ian Burns discusses his inventive ‘meta-cinematic’ exhibition, ‘In the Telling’. Presenting a network of close-circuit kinetic sculptures that work together to create live video footage inside the gallery, the exhibition invites audiences to suspend their disbelief and behold a moment of cinematic cliché and excess.

In this interview, Ian talks about his art process, influences and goes into the ideas behind works included in the exhibition such as the ACMI commissioned ‘Anywhere and Here’.

results.title: Ian Botham
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Cricketing legends”.
Richie Benaud and Jim Laker examine the cricketing achievements of one of the greatest all-rounders - Ian Botham. A controversial and colourful figure both on and off the field, Botham was a talented player who took some unbelievable catches in the slips and at the time of this programs’ production, was the only cricketer to score 5000 runs and take 300 wickets in Test Matches. Botham played for England and for the counties of Somerset and Worcestershire, making his debut in first-class cricket in the 1977 winning Ashes series. The highlights of Botham’s career are interspersed with an interview between Botham and Benaud.
